unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Baseball Logo
question_text:
A local baseball team is considering changing its logo.
A large survey of $5,000$ randomly selected subjects found that the majority of respondents preferred the new logo $(p = 0.02)$ to the old one.
Why might the team consider NOT changing their logo?

choices.text: The survey most likely contained high amounts of bias.
With large surveys, even a small difference can be considered statistically significant and give low p-values.
The $p$-value is too high to give any strong evidence of a preference.
There is no information to indicate that the distribution is approximately normal.
None of the solutions listed are correct; the team should change its logo.

solution:
Even a small difference can be considered statistically significant. Itâ€™s likely that only $50\%-51\%$ prefer the new logo over the old one. With such a small difference, it may not be worth the time and money to make the new logo.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the problem states that this is a random sample and assumes then that there is no bias.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a $p$-value of $0.02$ is considered quite low.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; the data will be approximately normal since $np$ and $n(1-p)$ are far greater than $10$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; see Choice 'B' explanation.
